questions.question: 1. When do we add a vertex, adjacent to a newly added vertex to MST, into Min-heap?

answers.a: If it is present in Min-heap
answers.b: If it is neither in MST nor in Min-heap.
answers.c: If it is present in MST
answers.d: If it is present in both Min-heap and MST

explanations.a: If a vertex is present in MST, then adding it again would cause the algorithm to get stuck in a loop.
explanations.c: We add the vertex which is still left to become a part of MST, and hence is not present in MST
explanations.d: We don’t add a vertex to MST if it is present in both Min-heap and MST to avoid redundancy, and loop.

questions.question: 2. How many edges are present in MST after k iterations?

explanations.a: Prim’s algorithm starts from a vertex, and after each iteration, it adds a new vertex and thus a new edge. Thus after k iterations, k edges will be present in MST.

questions.question: 3. For dense graphs, which data structure can be used to implement Prim’s Algorithm?

explanations.c: Using D-Heap or D-ary Heap, Prim’s algorithm can be executed in linear time.

answers.a: Heap can be used to implement Prim’s Algorithm
answers.b: Prim’s algorithm spans from one vertex to another
answers.c: Prim’s algorithm is an example of greedy algorithm
answers.d: Cycles in MST can get accepted by Prim’s Algorithm

explanations.d: If cycles are present in a MST, then it is not a tree. Prim’s Algorithm works in an efficient way such that it never accepts a cycle.
